Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of Early Endosperm Development in Maize
Award.AbstractNarration:
_____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

***
PI: Ramin Yadegari (University of Arizona)

CoPIs: Amy Clore (New College of Florida), Joanne Dannehoffer (Central Michigan University), Gary Drews (University of Utah) and Brian Larkins (University of Nebraska)


The goal of this research project is to understand the gene networks that control endosperm development and function in maize. The endosperm of the seed is biologically and economically important. More than 50% of the calories in the human diet originate from cereal endosperm, which also serves as a raw material for manufacturing numerous industrial products. Early endosperm development in maize, the period between 0 and 8 days after pollination, encompasses the time when the endosperm grows from a single cell into a multicellular structure composed of different cell types. Although the molecular mechanisms that control this period of development in maize have not been elucidated, they are likely to affect many important processes, including embryo nutrition, starch and storage protein accumulation during grain filling, and seed maturation. In this project a network of maize transcription factors expressed during early endosperm development will be identified, and their temporal and spatial expression patterns will be determined. The function of a subset of these genes will be characterized in maize and Arabidopsis plants. In addition, the cytological patterns of early endosperm development will be described in a diverse set of maize inbred lines. These inbreds are currently being genetically and phenotypically characterized by a large number of laboratories, and these data will make it possible to evaluate the importance of the identified genes to a variety of grain quality traits.

The broader educational impacts of this project will enhance the infrastructure of research and training at all the participating institutions through the continued instruction of undergraduate and graduate students and training of postdoctoral researchers. A significant component of the proposed research will involve faculty members at institutions with predominately (Central Michigan University CMU) or exclusively (New College of Florida NCF) undergraduate populations. Student researchers from CMU and NCF will have an opportunity to spend a summer each year at the University of Arizona and the University of Utah for further training and education. Undergraduate researchers will be recruited from the classroom, local community colleges, and underrepresented student populations at all institutions. In addition, an important goal of the project is to increase the representation of underrepresented minorities in science and to communicate science through outreach to K-12 teachers and to nonscientists. The scientific and educational outcomes of this project will be disseminated through the project website http://cals.arizona.edu/earlyendosperm and Gramene (http://www.gramene.org/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Endosperm is biologically and economically important. In all angiosperms, endosperm provides nutrients and signals to the embryo during seed development and the seedling during germination. In cereal grains, endosperm comprises a large proportion of the mature seed, contains large amounts of carbohydrates and proteins, and is an important source of food, feed, and industrial raw materials. Approximately, 50% of human calories are derived from cereal endosperm, either directly or indirectly through animal feed. Furthermore, cereal endosperm is used as a raw material for numerous industrial products including ethanol.

The long-term goal of our research has been to understand the gene networks controlling endosperm development and function in maize. This project was focused on early maize endosperm development encompassing 0-12 days after pollination (DAP) and including the coenocytic, cellularization, and early mitotic phases of endosperm development. During this period, the endosperm undergoes many rounds of mitosis without cytokinesis, forming a multi-nucleate structure (coenocytic phase), becomes fully cellularized (cellularization phase), and then undergoes a period of intense mitosis (early mitotic phase). The coenocytic and cellularization phases are major steps in endosperm development in cereals and most other species, and understanding these processes is central to understanding endosperm structure and function. The early mitotic phase gives rise to the body of cells comprising the starchy endosperm, and understanding how it is regulated is important, because most of the endosperm cells are produced during this time. Previous studies had shown that endosperm cell number is related to seed size, seed sink strength, and grain weight. Thus, an understanding of the molecular processes that regulate early endosperm development in maize could provide a means to develop strategies to increase cereal productivity, which in turn could have direct and indirect beneficial effects on human nutrition and economic development.

To provide a framework for gene network analysis, we studied the anatomical and structural characteristics of early endosperm in a reference maize accession in order to establish the developmental staging necessary for subsequent molecular studies. These included a combination of laser-capture microdissection and deep RNA sequencing technology that were used to generate a preliminary spatiotemporal map of all the genes expressed during early endosperm development in maize. The specific experiments carried out included: (1) A characterization of the cytological and morphometric features of early endosperm development in B73 maize inbred line, (2) A temporal profiling of mRNA populations activated during early kernel and endosperm development from 0 to 12 DAP, (3) Development of a robust laser-capture microdissection protocol for analysis of mRNAs in maize kernel compartments and cell types, (4) A profiling of mRNAs using laser-capture microdissection and development of co-expression networks for multiple cell types of the maize kernel at 8 DAP, and (5) Generation of a sub-network of genes regulated by the MYBR transcription factor protein MRP-1 in the BETL compartment of endosperm at 8 DAP.

This research also enhanced the infrastructure of research and training at our respective institutions through the continued instruction of undergraduate and graduate students and training of postdoctoral researchers.  A significant component of the proposed research involved faculty members at institutions with large undergraduate (CMU) or exclusively (NCF) undergraduate populations. Multiple student researchers from CMU and NCF spent a summer each year at the University of Arizona for further training and education. Undergraduate researchers were recruited from the classrooms and underrepresented student populations at all institutions. We also carried out major efforts in introducing K-12 students, their teachers and parents to the research in our laboratories. This was achieved through a series of guided tours of our laboratories and greenhouses, and by demonstrating our work in primary and middle-school classrooms, community gardens, and student science conventions.
